body: So in short, I think we will not do anything for now, please make sure you can run the relevant tests(lint, unittests) in your local env and use CI as a means to just safe check the last stage of the code
@tqchen @junrushao1994 Okay, let's then just keep it like this. I will rebase and commit again. Thanks.
LGTM!
link is broken.
I see. I would vote to throw error to start, and if we see more occurrence of such pattern, we can consider handling it properly.
I have raised PR https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1881. Thanks.

Wow! That certainly is weird to happen given the following definition on the official TensorFlow page: https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Graph

I have partially working patch for tensor flow too for various issues raised in discussion form on inception v4 and mobile net V2.

This patch is to ignore add_shapes and use proper infer by default to avoid unnecessary issues in future.
It would be great if you could help with review of the same.
Sure - I will be glad to. Could you please send me the link of commit / title of pull request?

cc @junrushao1994 please have another look.

@srkreddy1238 In https://github.com/srkreddy1238/tvm/commit/24665aef83d2287b331fac4718e62dcc11031f65 Shape operator will not be handled by from_onnx if the ishape_dict is not provided by the user. How do we handle the operator in such a case?

default axis=1 is 0 based indexing, and that is because usually batch_norm normalizes the channel dimension
@tqchen I think it is ready to land, could you please take a look? Thanks.
moved into #1851
fixed and tested
@tqchen I had addressed the review comment.
Thanks for the explanation; I've changed the default

Good code reuse. The question of defaults is interesting, since @tqchen suggested to go with no default shape for `full`, while the NNVM docs do mention defaults (we should be consistent either way). Are we sure we don't want a default `dtype` too? (The NNVM docs say `float32`.)

There are no default for zeros/ones, only for TensorAttrs (which is not exposed to python).
So I think we can have it maintain the same default for full.
Specific optimization is necessary for dilated conv2d and we do need some of them to skip unnecessary computations

I also got the same issue

@zhreshold can you also help review this PR?

This PR LGTM.

BTW, I am more interested in a standalone box NMS op so that GluonCV models can be used directly. @kevinthesun Do you know the progress?
NNVM BoxNMS op is already there. Topi version BoxNMS is done using hybrid frontend, and waiting for the ability to compile with hybrid frontend. @were Any update?
cc @nishi-t
Let us keep the convention of NNVM as it is, to allow backward compatibility. The full numpy consistency change need to will happen in relay
`simple_mode` skips the sanity check by `IRUseDefAnalysis`. So I added a test to show that we can detect such patterns.

@tqchen @kevinthesun 
I am facing a problem like this:
````Python
op = _ExternOp(input_placeholders, input_buffers, output_buffers, ..., body)
ret = [op.output(i) for i in range(len(output_buffers))]
return ret[0] if len(ret) == 1 else ret
````
Originally, what I am supposed to do is to register an op and return its output tensors, which seems to be OK, but the problem I am facing is that all the output tensors' names are same as the op's name.

Just as it is mentioned above, `return c, d` gives different names to the output tensors.

Also, if I want to give a different name to the tensor, how can I specify the relationship between the tensor and op?
@MarisaKirisame @jroesch @slyubomirsky @joshpoll  please review
This actually makes a lot of sense and simplifies several things on the front end. 👍
Thanks @wweic !

I just did a skim, and LGTM.
Should we rename typeparam -> typevar then?
We can discuss typeparam vs typevar later with @jroesch
The output tensor's name can be viewed as op_name.value0, opname.value1 which have different meaning. Note that under the hood tvm uses pointer uniqueness, so even if the name are the same it is fine
@MarisaKirisame @joshpoll Thanks for the reviews, I have made changes according to your comments
closed by #1898 , thanks @gaoxiong1
Good catch. Be sure to change the test for it as well.

OK. I know know what you mean --- no matter how users name the output tensors, we will finally convert all the tensors to name `foo.v0`, `foo.v1`, and etc.

Then a new problem comes when doing in-place. (or more accurately, it is not a problem. I just want to make sure it is acceptable):
````Python
out = foo(a)
sch = tvm.create_schedule(a.op)
tvm.build(sch, [out])
````
Say, `foo` is an in-place function call which transforms `a` to `out`. They are essentially the same buffer with alias, but I CANNOT use `a` when compilation. I need to force users to pass `out`, or the compiler cannot find the buffer in the binds.
Agreed with previous comments, this is certainly a good simplification to make. LGTM, for the most part.

For now, we could avoid supporting inplace functions, if we want to create an inplace op, we can do 
```python
out = foo(a)
sch = tvm.create_schedule(a.op)
buffer = tvm.decl_buffer(shape=out.shape)
tvm.build(sch, [buffer], binds={a:buffer, out:buffer})
```
I am refusing not to support in-place because it is some kind of "rollback" --- it is supported before but disabled just because the "glue" to the framework.
Thanks @slyubomirsky @joshpoll @MarisaKirisame , this is merged
The example I gave kinda of support inplace operations
I am not completely sure this should be the semantics for every alpha equal checking, as the same incomplete type appearing in similar locations naturally has certain meanings.

For now, I think it is good enough.
My question is that  we have already have buffer binds stored in Op's attributes, so can we do it spontaneously?

Some final comments. Also it would also be really nice if we return a wrapper class in python to support the following sugar

```python
x, mask = relay.nn.dropout(input_val)
```

In order to support this, we could do the following trick
```python
class TupleWrapper(tvm.node._ffi.NodeGeneric):
    """Wrapper class of Tuple expression with known size."""
    def __init__(self, tuple_value, size):
        self.tuple_value = tuple_value
        self.size = size
   # pass the tuple value if itself  get passed as argument to a FFI function
   def asnode(self):
        return self.tuple_value
    # implement __getitem__, __len__, so it can behave like an array
```
And in the python function we wrap the return value by TupleExpr(result_of_dropout, 2)
It sounds good to me, as long as the behavior is well documented
Ok

sorry about that. @anijain2305 
please check it again:
```import tvm                                                                                                                         

def test():
    ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
    loop1 = 4 
    loop2 = 9998
    tile = 39991
    with ib.for_range(0,loop2,'i') as i:
        with ib.for_range(0,loop1,'j') as j:
            head1 = i 
            head2 = j 
            with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 < tile - head2)):
                with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 < tile - head2)):
                    ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float16',"cce_intrisic",head1))

    stmt = ib.get()
    stmt = tvm.ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt,True)
    print stmt

test()
```
@tqchen I don't quite understand. Do you have specific examples where this is not the desired behavior? Both @MarisaKirisame and I have cases where this PR gives us the desired behavior.
@jroesch @slyubomirsky @yzhliu @zhiics @ZihengJiang  please review

The question is that whether the following two code alpha-equals to each other, note that first one have shares ```?a`` among two type annotations and that could potentially represents a type constraint.

```
let x: ?a = 1;
let y: ?a = 2
x
```

```
let x: ?a = 1
let y: ?b = 2
x
```

Hi, according the [community issue convention](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/f721a645cd77661a8284559d676ef20f91eaa771/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md), it's recommended to post to https://discuss.tvm.ai first. The community will help investigate and convert it into an actionable item laster as a github issue. And it's also very helpful to provide the exact command you use that cause the error and provide as much error log as possible.

@anijain2305 what LLVM version do I need to run test_conv_int8_intel.py? I'm getting 

```
AssertionError: llvm.x86.avx512.pmaddubs.w.512 is not an LLVM intrinsic
```
with LLVM 6.0.
@tqchen can you give it another look? I had addressed all comment.

I think the declarations of 1x1 and common are same. 

Is it easy to merge them into a single template? Although this may enlarge search space and make tuning last longer.
If it is not easy, we can just merge this.

This error is due to older LLVM version. Looks like, LLVM 6.0 does not support AVX512BW instructions.
I am using LLVM 8.0 and it works with that.
Good idea, I'll add the tuple wrapper and use it for these functions
Agree with @merrymercy that the compute decl are the same which can be merged. While the schedule are slightly different, I guess we still need two templates?

Apologies for my inattentive reading, I thought the initial change was _adding_ a check for kind, not eliminating the pointer equality check. I agree that two different type vars should not be considered alpha-equal simply because they have the same kind (perhaps we could do the same thing as with ordinary vars as in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1900?)

I think you are using CPU backends.

Currently, we always create an intermediate buffer for dilation (compute_root). We can use compute_inline + unroll to eliminate multiplications of zeros and large intermediate buffers. Significant performance gain can be obtained here.
@siju-samuel could you review again?
@jroesch Any update on the changes?

@joshpoll I had been using incompletetypenode to signal 'infer for me'.
I switch to None and all is fine.

If we can use None instead of IncompleteType nodes, what is the purpose of the latter? Are they not meant to be specified by users but only used internally by the type checker? If that's the case, perhaps we should make a stronger/clearer distinction between these two types of nodes.
Most parts of decl are the same, except kernel shape, so that computes are slightly different. For templates, I prefer keeping two templates. This makes auto-tuning easier.
If we can build a search space to cover both cases, it will be better.
Looks like using None for a function return type causes a nullptr exception during alpha equality checking?
@imorinaga Any updates?

If we want to use a single template, certain parameter won't be used in either common or 1x1 case. I feel this might cause a bit confusion. Also I have already completed tuning for gluon cv models on avx512 and avx2 cpu. How difficult is it to directly transfer records to new templates?

As long as we allow nullptrs in function return types and in variable types, I think I can fully switch my annotations to None instead of IncompleteType. I can close this PR and submit a new one with changes to alpha equality that add more type `defined()` checks if that sounds good to you all. I've already made the change in the text format branch.
We can keep two different schedules. But the compute declarations are equivalent. Because they only differ in kernel dimensions whose lengths are one. Their layouts in memory are the same.
Thanks @slyubomirsky @yzhliu @zhiics , i have updated the code
Supporting None sounds good
@yzhliu Hey sorry, I was on vacation for the past two weeks will put some cycles on this today.
general design question: is it possible to cache the hash value in an attr instead of computing it everytime it was needed? doing so allow a small constant cost to calling hash.

just tried it out :), looks like it works
![output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2239616/46982159-073b6080-d090-11e8-8f26-6a93c89ebc78.png)

It also works on 1080 Ti with fallback configs.
Once this is merged we can release a set of tuned operators; comparing the performance with DarkNet will be interesting in that case.

@MarisaKirisame I have thought about it, I think it is a good thing to do if everything is immutable. In general, we are not going to hash Attrs itself but might hash the entire program and it might make sense to cache the thing somewhere

I think we still need to revise the semantics of alpha equality for IncompleteTypes, though, like Steven suggested, since with just pointer equality two structurally identical expressions aren't alpha equal.
